intro: Gilia lutea var. aurea, commonly known as the golden gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It has hairy, branched stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine pubescence. The flowers are tubular with five lobes and are pollinated primarily by bees and other insects.
